Detailed Description

Routines for sampling various distributions.

Author:
Bryan Herman

Note, all values are double precision, i.e. about 16 digits. We could use real's (about 8 digits), but what happens when we sample a billion times?

Function/Subroutine Documentation

double precision pdfs::get_collision_distance ( double precision,intent(in)  xs)

Sample a particle's distance to next collision.

This only applies to the slab with the given cross section. If the particles gets to a boundary, a new distance must be sampled with the appropriate cross section.

Parameters:
[in]xsThe cross section of the slab traversed.
Returns:
The distance to be traveled.

integer pdfs::get_collision_type ( double precision,intent(in)  absxs,
double precision,intent(in)  scattxs,
double precision,intent(in)  totxs 
)

Sample the type of collision a particle undergoes.

Cross sections are nothing but probabilities. If a particle can undergo either absorption or scattering, the probability of each is simply

and

respectively. Things get way more complicated in multigroup transport with multiple collision types. It's even worse for continuous energy treatments. Just ask Paul.

Parameters:
[in]absxsThe cross section of the slab traversed.
[in]scattxsThe cross section of the slab traversed.
[in]totxsThe cross section of the slab traversed.
Returns:
The type of collision (1 for abs, 2 for scatter)

double precision pdfs::get_particle_mu ( )

Sample the particle's direction (for the source).

This assumes an isotropic source in the LAB system.

Returns:
The particle's direction at birth.
